newsitem.title: USA: GOLF-OGRIN USES HOME FIELD ADVANTAGE TO TAKE TEXAS OPEN LEAD.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-OGRIN USES HOME FIELD ADVANTAGE TO TAKE TEXAS OPEN LEAD.

text.p: David Ogrin took advantage of his home field advantage to secure a one-stroke lead after the second round of the $1.2 million Texas Open golf tournament on Friday.
Ogrin, who lives nearby and has played the LaCantera course some 50 times, used his intimate knowledge of the 7,001-yard layout to compile nine birdies in a seven-under-par 65 round.

The Texan heads into weekend play at nine-under 135, one stroke ahead of Jay Haas, who fired a 66. Bob Tway (67), budding superstar Tiger Woods (68), and overnight co-leader John Huston (71) were two shots back at 137.
Ogrin put together two impressive streaks, reeling off five successive birdies from the fifth hole, and four in a row beginning at the 12th.
"Those two runs made the 65," said Ogrin, 38, who has not won since joining the PGA Tour in 1983.
"It didn't surprise me at all that I did this, although 65 is by far my best round on the course."
Haas, a two-time Texas Open winner at its previous venue of Oak Hill, also feels at home at the event's new site.
Starting his round at the 10th hole, Haas made only one birdie on the back nine, before charging home with five on the front side.

Woods, in contrast, blistered the back nine after a sluggish front nine. He dropped two shots on the outward half, primarily as a result of four-putting the sixth green, where he rushed because his group was being timed for slow play.
Woods negotiated the back nine in 30 strokes, thanks to six birdies and three pars, to move into the hunt for his second consecutive victory.

"Going into the weekend you want to be in with a chance to win," said Woods, the three-time U.S. Amateur champion who won last week's Las Vegas Invitational in only his fifth start since turning professional.
Defending champion Duffy Waldorf bogeyed his final hole to miss by one stroke the cut, which fell at one-over 145.
